facts.text: Appeal by the State of Bombay with special leave against acquittal by Bombay High Court of respondent Vishnu Ramchandra

anchor.surface_text: This is an appeal by the State of Bombay, with the special leave of this Court, against the order of acquittal by the High Court of Bombay of the respondent, Vishnu Ramchandra, who was prosecuted under s. 142 of the Bombay Police Act and sentenced to six months rigorous im- prisonment by the Presidency Magistrate, 2nd Court, Mazagaon, Bombay.

facts.text: On November 16, 1949, Vishnu Ramchandra convicted under s. 380 and 114 of the Indian Penal Code, sentenced to one month rigorous imprisonment

anchor.surface_text: On November 16, 1949, Vishnu Ramehandra was companyvicted under s. 380 and 114 of the Indian Penal Code, and sentenced to one months rigorous imprisonment. On October 15, 1957, the Deputy Commissioner of Police, Bombay, acting under s. 57 a  of the Bombay Police Act  22 of 1951 , passed an order against Vishnu Ramchandra which was to operate for one year, externing him from the limits of Greater Bombay.

facts.text: On October 15, 1957, Deputy Commissioner of Police, Bombay, passed order under s. 57 Bombay Police Act 22 of 1951 externing Vishnu Ramchandra from limits of Greater Bombay for one year

anchor.surface_text: On October 15, 1957, the Deputy Commissioner of Police, Bombay, acting under s. 57 a  of the Bombay Police Act  22 of 1951 , passed an order against Vishnu Ramchandra which was to operate for one year, externing him from the limits of Greater Bombay. At that time, a prosecution under s. 411 of the Indian Penal Code was pending against Vishnu Ramchandra, and he was number immediately externed, to enable him to attend the case.

facts.text: Prosecution under s. 411 IPC pending against Vishnu Ramchandra at time of externment order, not immediately externed to attend case

anchor.surface_text: At that time, a prosecution under s. 411 of the Indian Penal Code was pending against Vishnu Ramchandra, and he was number immediately externed, to enable him to attend the case. This prosecution came to an end on July 10, 1958, and resulted in his acquittal.

facts.text: Prosecution under s. 411 IPC against Vishnu Ramchandra ended on July 10, 1958, resulted in acquittal

anchor.surface_text: This prosecution came to an end on July 10, 1958, and resulted in his acquittal. Immediately afterwards, a companystable took him outside the limits of Greater Bombay, and left him there.

facts.text: Immediately after acquittal, constable took Vishnu Ramchandra outside limits of Greater Bombay and left him there

anchor.surface_text: Immediately afterwards, a companystable took him outside the limits of Greater Bombay, and left him there. The prosecution case was that he returned to Greater Bombay, and was arrested at Pydhonie on August 24, 1958.

facts.text: Vishnu Ramchandra returned to Greater Bombay and arrested at Pydhonie on August 24, 1958

anchor.surface_text: The prosecution case was that he returned to Greater Bombay, and was arrested at Pydhonie on August 24, 1958. He was prosecuted under s. 142 of the Bombay Police Act. His plea that he was forcibly brought back to Pydhonie and arrested was number accepted by the Presidency Magistrate, and he was companyvicted.

anchor.surface_text: He was prosecuted under s. 142 of the Bombay Police Act. His plea that he was forcibly brought back to Pydhonie and arrested was number accepted by the Presidency Magistrate, and he was companyvicted. He filed a revision application, which was heard by a learned single Judge of the High Court of Bombay.

facts.text: Vishnu Ramchandra filed revision application heard by single Judge of Bombay High Court

anchor.surface_text: He filed a revision application, which was heard by a learned single Judge of the High Court of Bombay. Three companytentions were raised before the High Court. The first was that the Deputy Commissioner of Police had number applied his mind to the facts of the case before making the order of externment.

facts.text: Three contentions raised before High Court: 1. Deputy Commissioner did not apply mind; 2. s.57 prospective; 3. belief based on pending prosecution that disappeared after acquittal

anchor.surface_text: Three companytentions were raised before the High Court. The first was that the Deputy Commissioner of Police had number applied his mind to the facts of the case before making the order of externment. The second was that s. 57 of the Bombay Police Act was prospective, and companyld number be made applicable, unless the companyviction on which the action of externment was based, took place after the companying into force of that Act. The third was that the belief entertained by the Deputy Commissioner that Vishnu Ramchandra was likely to engage himself in the companymission of an offence similar to that for which he was prosecuted was based on the prosecution which was then pending, and that that ground disappeared after his acquittal.

facts.text: High Court held second ground good, did not consider first and third, acquitted respondent

Appeal by special leave from the judgment and order dated November 25, 1958, of the former Bombay High Court in Criminal Revision Application No. 1393 of 1958 arising out of the judgment and order dated September 18, 1958, of the Presidency Magistrate 11 Class, Mazagaon at Bombay in Case No. 1101/P of 1958.

This is an appeal by the State of Bombay, with the special leave of this Court, against the order of acquittal by the High Court of Bombay of the respondent, Vishnu Ramchandra, who was prosecuted under s. 142 of the Bombay Police Act and sentenced to six months rigorous im- prisonment by the Presidency Magistrate, 2nd Court, Mazagaon, Bombay.

anchor.surface_text: On October 15, 1957, the Deputy Commissioner of Police, Bombay, acting under s. 57 a  of the Bombay Police Act  22 of 1951 , passed an order against Vishnu Ramchandra which was to operate for one year, externing him from the limits of Greater Bombay. At that time, a prosecution under s. 411 of the Indian Penal Code was pending against Vishnu Ramchandra, and he was number immediately externed, to enable him to attend the case.

The prosecution case was that he returned to Greater Bombay, and was arrested at Pydhonie on August 24, 1958. He was prosecuted under s. 142 of the Bombay Police Act. His plea that he was forcibly brought back to Pydhonie and arrested was number accepted by the Presidency Magistrate, and he was companyvicted.

The cardinal principle is that statutes must always be interpreted prospectively, unless the language of the statutes makes them retrospective, either expressly or by necessary implication.

arguments.claim: Statutes must always be interpreted prospectively, unless the language makes them retrospective expressly or by necessary implication

anchor.surface_text: The question whether an enactment is meant to operate prospectively or retrospectively has to be decided in accordance with well-settled principles. The cardinal principle is that statutes must always be interpreted prospectively, unless the language of the statutes makes them retrospective, either expressly or by necessary implication.

arguments.claim: Penal statutes which create new offences are always prospective, but penal statutes which create disabilities are sometimes interpreted retrospectively when there is clear intendment

anchor.surface_text: Penal statutes which create new offences are always prospective, but penal statutes which create disabilities, though ordinarily interpreted prospectively, are sometimes interpreted retrospectively when there is a clear intendment that they are to be applied to past events.

arguments.claim: An Act designed to protect the public against acts of a harmful character may be construed retrospectively if the language admits

anchor.surface_text: Another principle which also applies is that an Act designed to protect the public against acts of a harmful character may be construed retrospectively, if the language admits such an interpretation, even though it may equally have a prospective meaning.

arguments.claim: The verb 'has been' is in the present perfect tense and expresses a hypothesis without regard to time

anchor.surface_text: It remains only to consider if the language of the section bars an action based on past actions before the Act was passed. The verb has been is in the present perfect tense, and may mean either shall have been or shall be. Looking, however, to the scheme of the enactment as a whole and particularly the other portions of it, it is manifest that the former meaning is intended.

arguments.claim: s.57 does not create a new offence but is designed to protect the public from undesirable persons convicted of certain offences

anchor.surface_text: Now s. 57 of the Bombay Police Act, 1951, does not create a new offence nor makes punishable that which was not an offence. It is designed to protect the public from the activities of undesirable persons who have been convicted of offences of a particular kind.

arguments.claim: An externment order under s.57 must be made bona fide, taking into account a conviction which is sufficiently proximate in time; each case depends on its own facts

anchor.surface_text: An externment order, however, to satisfy the requirements of s. 57 of the Bombay Police Act, must be made bona fide, taking into account a conviction which is sufficiently proximate in time. Since no absolute rule can be laid down, each case must depend on its own facts.

holdings.text: The High Court was not right in the view it had taken of s. 57 of the Act

anchor.surface_text: We have heard Mr. Dhebar in support of the appeal, and, in our opinion, the High Court was not right in the view it had taken of s. 57 of the Act. The question whether an enactment is meant to operate prospectively or retrospectively has to be decided in accordance with well- settled principles.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Applied settled principles of statutory interpretation distinguishing penal from protective provisions, citing English and Indian precedents allowing retrospective construction for public protection where language permits

holdings.text: s. 57 of the Bombay Police Act, 1951, does not create a new offence nor makes punishable that which was not an offence. It is designed to protect the public from the activities of undesirable persons who have been convicted of offences of a particular kind

anchor.surface_text: Now s. 57 of the Bombay Police Act, 1951, does not create a new offence nor makes punishable that which was not an offence. It is designed to protect the public from the activities of undesirable persons who have been convicted of offences of a particular kind. The section only enables the authorities to take notice of their convictions and to put them outside the area of their activities, so that the public may be protected against a repetition of such activities.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Purposive interpretation as protective measure against repetition of crimes by convicted persons, not new punishment, supported by precedents like Queen v. Vine and Rex v. Austin

holdings.text: The Act in question was thus not applied retrospectively but prospectively

anchor.surface_text: An offender who has been punished may be restrained in his acts and conduct by some legislation, which takes notice of his antecedents but so long as the action taken against him is after the Act comes into force, the statute cannot be said to be applied retrospectively. The Act in question was thus not applied retrospectively but prospectively.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Order passed after Act is prospective application even if based on past conviction, as action restrains future conduct

holdings.text: the language of the section bars an action based on past actions before the Act was passed [no, it does not]; The verb has been is in the present perfect tense... it is manifest that the former meaning is intended [past convictions]

anchor.surface_text: It remains only to consider if the language of the section bars an action based on past actions before the Act was passed. The verb has been is in the present perfect tense, and may mean either shall have been or shall be . Looking, however, to the scheme of the enactment as a whole and particularly the other portions of it, it is manifest that the former meaning is intended.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Textual analysis of present perfect tense as hypothetical without temporal limit, harmonious with overall scheme, citing Ex Parte Pratt and Bourke v. Nutt

holdings.text: An externment order, however, to satisfy the requirements of s. 57 of the Bombay Police Act, must be made bona fide, taking into account a conviction which is sufficiently proximate in time. Since no absolute rule can be laid down, each case must depend on its own facts

anchor.surface_text: An externment order, however, to satisfy the requirements of s. 57 of the Bombay Police Act, must be made bona fide, taking into account a conviction which is sufficiently proximate in time. Since no absolute rule can be laid down, each case must depend on its own facts.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Requirement derived from purpose of section for effective public protection; factual determination case-specific without fixed rule

anchor.surface_text: Midland Rly. Co. v. Pye 1

precedents.cited_proposition: Penal statutes are construed prospectively unless legislature intention for retrospectivity is clear, plain and unambiguous as retrospective operation shocks sense of justice
precedents.cited_holding: Those whose duty it is to administer the law very properly guard against giving to an Act of Parliament a retrospective operation, unless the intention of the legislature that it should be so construed is expressed in clear, plain and unambiguous language because it manifestly shocks ones sense of justice that an act, legal at the time of doing it, should be made unlawful by some new enactment

anchor.surface_text: Rex v. Birthwhistle 1

precedents.cited_proposition: Statutes passed to supply a cure to an existing evil may be retrospective even without express words
precedents.cited_holding: Scores of Acts are retrospective, and may without express words be taken to be retrospective, since they are passed to supply a cure to an existing evil. Indeed, in that case which arose under the Married Women Maintenance in Case of Desertion Act, 1886, the Act was held retrospective without express words

anchor.surface_text: Queen v. Vine 2

precedents.cited_proposition: Act designed to protect public against harmful acts may be construed retrospectively if language admits, even if penal in nature
precedents.cited_holding: the object of the enactment is not to punish offenders, but to protect the public against public houses in which spirits are retailed being kept by persons of doubtful character... to import the intention to protect the public against persons convicted in the past as well as in future

anchor.surface_text: Ex Parte Pratt 1

precedents.cited_proposition: Present tense in statute may not limit to acts after the Act; used as present tense of logic or hypothesis without regard to time
precedents.cited_holding: no reliance can be placed on the words I commit as showing that only acts of bankruptcy committed after the Act came into operation are intended... the present tense is used, not in relation to time, but as the present tense of logic... to express a hypothesis, without regard to time

anchor.surface_text: Bourke v. Nutt 2

precedents.cited_proposition: Time to consider present tense is when court acts, not when condition arose; even if retrospective, public benefit statutes not restricted like penal ones
precedents.cited_holding: when the present tense is used in this statute s. 32 of the Bankruptcy Act, 1883 the time to be considered is the time at which the Court has to act, and not the time at which the condition of things on which it has to act came into existence... even if it could be said that it is retrospective its enactments are solely for the public benefit, and the rule that restricts the operation of a penal retrospective statute does not apply

anchor.surface_text: Ganesan v. A. K. Joscelyne 1

precedents.cited_proposition: Where object of Act is to protect public from undesirable persons with conviction stigma, ordinary rule against retrospectivity need not be strictly applied
precedents.cited_holding: in spite of the ordinary... cardinal rule of construction that statutes... ought not to be so construed as to given them a retrospective operation unless there is a clear provision... there is another principle... where the object of an Act is not to inflict punishment on anyone but to protect the public from undesirable persons, bearing the stigma of a conviction or misconduct on their character, the ordinary rule of construction need not be strictly applied

anchor.surface_text: Taher Saifuddin v. Tyebbhai Moosaji 2

precedents.cited_proposition: Same principles applied to protect public from undesirable persons

precedents.citation: The Queen Inhabitants of St. Mary Whitechapel 3

anchor.surface_text: The Queen Inhabitants of St. Mary Whitechapel 3

precedents.case_name: The Queen v. Inhabitants of St. Mary Whitechapel
precedents.cited_proposition: Statute prospective in direct operation but draws on antecedent facts without being retrospective
precedents.cited_holding: the statute is in its direct operation prospective, as it relates to future removals only, and that it is not properly called a retrospective statute because a part of the requisites for its action is drawn from time antecedent to its passing

anchor.surface_text: Rex v. Austin 1

precedents.cited_proposition: No vested right in past crimes; future legislation can consider previous history without retrospectivity
precedents.cited_holding: No man has such a vested right in his past crimes and their consequences as would entitle him to insist that in no future legislation shall any regard whatever be had to his previous history

anchor.surface_text: Ex Parte Pratt 2

precedents.cited_proposition: Present perfect tense 'has been' used to express hypothesis without regard to time
precedents.cited_holding: is used to express a hypothesis, without regard to time

anchor.surface_text: At the hearing before us, the respondent was number represented. We have heard Mr. Dhebar in support of the appeal, and, in our opinion, the High Court was number right in the view it had taken of s. 57 of the Act.

outcome.relief_summary: High Court not right in holding s. 57 prospective only; section applies to past convictions if bona fide and proximate

anchor.surface_text: We have heard Mr. Dhebar in support of the appeal, and, in our opinion, the High Court was not right in the view it had taken of s. 57 of the Act. The question whether an enactment is meant to operate prospectively or retrospectively has to be decided in accordance with well- settled principles.

At the hearing before us, the respondent was number represented. We have heard Mr. Dhebar in support of the appeal, and, in our opinion, the High Court was number right in the view it had taken of s. 57 of the Act.

anchor.surface_text: An offender who has been punished may be restrained in his acts and conduct by some legislation, which takes notice of his antecedents but so long as the action taken against him is after the Act comes into force, the statute cannot be said to be applied retrospectively. The Act in question was thus not applied retrospectively but prospectively.

At the hearing before us, the respondent was number represented. We have heard Mr. Dhebar in support of the appeal, and, in our opinion, the High Court was number right in the view it had taken of s. 57 of the Act.

anchor.surface_text: It remains only to consider if the language of the section bars an action based on past actions before the Act was passed. The verb has been is in the present perfect tense, and may mean either shall have been or shall be . Looking, however, to the scheme of the enactment as a whole and particularly the other portions of it, it is manifest that the former meaning is intended.

At the hearing before us, the respondent was number represented. We have heard Mr. Dhebar in support of the appeal, and, in our opinion, the High Court was number right in the view it had taken of s. 57 of the Act.

anchor.surface_text: An externment order, however, to satisfy the requirements of s. 57 of the Bombay Police Act, must be made bona fide, taking into account a conviction which is sufficiently proximate in time. Since no absolute rule can be laid down, each case must depend on its own facts.

At the hearing before us, the respondent was number represented. We have heard Mr. Dhebar in support of the appeal, and, in our opinion, the High Court was number right in the view it had taken of s. 57 of the Act.
